    >  seems that everybody has it's own way of doing things. 
    > What we do is simply
    > put the test classes with the code, in the same package & 
    > the same project.
    > We use different project & packages for special test 
    > classes (AllTests,
    > etc..).

One of the disadvantages to this is that it makes it a little harder to have
that solitary project that will be responsible to run all tests, not
impossible by any means, it just takes more doing.

    > I didn't found any real problem with having the test go 
    > with the production
    > code. Actually I like it. You can never lose track of the 
    > tests, and you can
    > run them in (pre-)production if you want, just to ensure 
    > that production env
    > (soft&hardware) behaves like dev.

This can be accomplished without having the tests side-by-side with your
production code.  Just include them in the release.
 
    > Because we have a naming convention where every test 
    > class name begins with
    > "Test", it's also pretty easy to manipulate them when exporting.
    > Why hide the tests? I'm proud of them! :) And I want them 
    > to be seen right
    > aside the class they test, so it gives a visual clue that 
    > they need to
    > follow the evolution of the class. Anyway.... :)

A moot point from my perspective, but your mileage probably varies.

-Jason
